It appears doubtful that the diffe 
rent types depend <u>solely<\u> upon tem 
perature. If so, the temperature va 
rying in the different parts of the ignited va 
pour of carbon, different types may 
be seen simultaneously. We shall 
not now discuss the influence, which 
the coexistence of foreign gases might 
have on the spectra of vapour of carbon,
nor may we here decide, whether or 
not, in the lower temperature of the 
flame a gaseous compound of carbon,
not being entirely decomposed, ex 
hibits, with the spectrum of the vapour 
of carbon, simultaneously the spec 
trum of the undecomposed gas.
In the spectrum of cyanogen for 
instance we got no visible traces 
of the spectrum of nitrogen (origi 
nating from the decomposed gas)
<u>ei<\u>[whe]ther we supplied the flame by a 
jet of oxygen or we operated in open 
air. But in both cases there is no 
reason not to admit, that the bands 
which are not seen in the case of any 
other compound of carbon, were 
owing to the undecomposed cyano 
gen.+
+ See (61).
